dod.SDabst: The Chemical and Physical Properties Division at NIST is engaged in an effort to collect, organize and disseminate all available enthalpies of reaction and formation of organic compounds. This is the first release of these data, covering the literature up to June 1996. The immediate objective of this effort is to accurately record these data, even if derived from indirect measurements such as appearance potentials and radical recombination energies. A longer range objective is to evaluate and when possible correct errors in the original data as well as to add additional relevant data, especially enthalpies of vaporization and sublimation. These data will also serve as a basis for improving the accuracy and coverage of thermochemical estimation methods.
dod.SDauth: Web-Page, W.
dod.SDedit: National Institute of Standards and Techniligy (NIST)

dod.SDauth: Greenwood, N.N., Earnshaw, A.

dod.SDabst: The edition is an updated electronic copy of the Third Millennium Ideal Gas and Condensed Phase Thermochemical Database for Combustion with Updates from Active Thermochemical Tables (report TAE 960 Table 4). It includes ideal gas thermodynamic data in polynomial form, for species used in combustion and air pollution.

dod.SDabst: The handbook consists of four volumes, earch of them is devided into two Parts. Part 1 is a description and critical analysis of all selected thermodynamic data, as well as the values derivatived by authors on the basis of selected data. Part 2 consists of tabulated data (selected and derived) in the temperature range of 100 - 6000K; for 31 gaseous species - till 10000K. The second varial coefficient and critical constants are given for 21 substances.
dod.SDauth: Gurvich, L.V., Veyts, I.V., Medvedev, V.A., Bergman, G.A., Hachkuruzov, G.A.,
dod.SDtitl: Thermodynamic properties of individual substances. Fourth Edition: H, O, F, Cl, Br, I, NG, S, N, P (in Russian)

dod.SDabst: Metallurgical, materials, ceramic and chemical engineers worldwide will welcome this new compilation of thermochemical data by Professor Barin. Here they will find the most comprehensive tables yet available for the thermodynamic properties of pure substances as a function of temperature at 100" intervals. Almost twenty-four hundred substances are included - the elements, and compounds of two, three, and four elements. The vast majority of substances are inorganic, but Dr. Barin has included a generous selection of the more common hydrocarbons, carbohydrates, and a few chlorinated hydrocarbons. The format of the tables conforms to that of the JANAF tables, and SI units are employed.
dod.SDauth: Barin, I.
Smith, J.F., Carlson, O.N., Peterson, D.T., Scott, T.E.
dod.SDnote: The Chemical Thermodynamics of Actinide Element and Compounds

dod.SDabst: CODATA is particularly concerned with omprovement of the quality and accessibility of data that span the interest of several scientific disciplines. Thermodynamics, with its broad importance in chemistry, physics, geology and several branches of engineering, is clearly such a field. Thus CODATA has had an active interest in thermodynamic data since its inception.
dod.SDauth: Garvin, D., Parker, V.B., White, H.J.
dod.SDnote: Report of the CODATA Task Group on Chemical Thermodynamic Tables

dod.SDabst: An adiabatic drop calorimeter has been used to measure the enthalpy of RuTe2 in the temperature interval 373 to 1473 K, relative to 298 K. The second-law value obtained for the standard enthalpy of formation and the standard entropy for RuTe2 are: Hfo (298 K) = (-33.5 � 0.7) kcal*mol-1 and So(298 K) = (21.4 � 0.6) cal*K-1 mol-1 respectively.
dod.SDauth: Svendsen, S.R.
dod.SDtitl: Decomposition pressures and thermodynamic properties of RuTe2.

dod.SDabst: The constitution of the Ru - Te system was investigated in the concentration range 0-70 at% Te between 400 and 1200�C usind metallography, X-ray diffraction, X-ray microanalysis and differential thermal analysis.
dod.SDauth: Bernath, S., Kleykamp, H., Smykatz-Kloss, W.
dod.SDtitl: The constitution of the ruthenium - tellurium system.
